subject: Using JWhich to resolve classpath problems with Ant...
msgSnippet: I don t know if other people have this problem or not, but I ve used Mike Clark s JWhich to debug some classpath problems with my Ant scripts. I typically
messageBody:
I don't know if other people have this problem or not,
but I've used Mike Clark's JWhich to debug some classpath
problems with my Ant scripts. I typically build explicit
classpaths in my ant scripts (usually out of properties
defined in runlib.properties).

This is especially handy in EJB testing where sometimes
the JRE I use is important {BAD WebSphere!, bad, bad!},
so I put a JWhich target that takes in a property (findclass)
that I can pass in on the command line. Here I've defaulted
it to finding JWhich (not typically useful).

[The following file is ONLY the JWhich target]

------------- JWhich.xml ------------------------
<project name="JWhich" default="JWhich" basedir=".">

<property name="findclass" value="JWhich"/>

<!-- ========================================= -->
<!-- Defines the classpath used for running. -->
<!-- ========================================= -->
<path id="base.classpath">
<pathelement path="${java.class.path}" />
<!-- Put the location of JWhich in the classpath -->
<pathelement location="C:/junit3.7" />
</path>

<target name="JWhich" description="Determine where given class is">
<java classname="JWhich"
fork="yes">
<classpath>
<path refid="base.classpath" />
</classpath>
<arg value="${findclass}"/>
</java>
</target>

</project>
-------------------------------------

Richard.
